Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a significant change in international sanctions policy affecting sports is officially enacted by at least one major governing body (e.g., the United Nations, European Union, or a major sports federation such as FIFA or the International Olympic Committee). A 'significant change' is defined as: 1) The lifting or imposition of sanctions that directly impacts the participation of athletes or teams in international competitions; 2) Changes in eligibility criteria for athletes or teams from sanctioned nations; or 3) A formal change in the rules governing international sports events that affects how sanctions are applied. The change must be documented in official announcements or resolutions from the governing bodies and reported by at least three reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times). Temporary measures or discussions do not count towards this question's resolution.

P.title: Will the US Senate pass significant legislation regarding nuclear safety standards by 2025?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the United States Senate has passed legislation that significantly alters or establishes new nuclear safety standards. Significant legislation is defined as any bill that: 
- Introduces new safety regulations for nuclear power plants, including but not limited to operational, environmental, or safety protocols. 
- Amends existing laws such as the Atomic Energy Act or the Nuclear Waste Policy Act in a way that enhances safety standards. 
The legislation must be officially signed into law by the President of the United States. The resolution will rely on official congressional records and reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) for verification. If multiple bills are introduced, at least one must be passed and signed into law for the resolution to be Yes.

Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the US House of Representatives has passed legislation that significantly alters nuclear safety standards. Q.title: Will there be a major public safety incident related to nuclear facilities in the US before 2025?
Q.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, any of the following incidents occur at a nuclear facility in the United States:
- A significant release of radioactive material that poses a threat to public health or safety, as determined by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) or the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).
- An incident that results in a fatality or serious injury to workers or the public due to operational failures or accidents at a nuclear facility.
- A major security breach at a nuclear facility that leads to unauthorized access to nuclear materials or poses a credible threat to public safety.

The incidents must be reported and verified by the NRC, or acknowledged by at least two reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). Minor incidents or operational issues that do not result in public harm or significant safety threats do not count towards this question's resolution.
